description.narrative:
UNICEF har ansökt om finansiering på 49,4 miljoner kronor för stöd till sitt landprogram avseende de tematiska områdena Barns Skydd och Socialt Inkluderande mellan 2016 och 2018. Den föreslagna interventionens komponenter och uppsatta resultat har ett starkt jämlikhets- och rättighetsbaserat fokus, med ’Socialt Inkluderande’ både som övergripande tema och som integrerat med Barns Skydd, HIV och Aids, Vatten, Sanitet och Hygien samt Utbildning.
Interventionen är i linje med svenska prioriteringar, vilka syftar till att stärka barns rättigheter som en del av socialt inkluderande och fattigdomsbekämpning. Sidas mänskliga rättigheters-perspektiv placerar barn i centrum för utvecklingsagendan.
Resultatområdet för socialt inkluderande ska definiera strategier för att stärka resiliens, speciellt i sårbara områden som är särskilt utsatta för extremt klimat så som torka. Det finns ett brådskande behov av att arbeta med förebyggande interventioner för att skydda barn från att drabbas. De föreslagna interventionerna ska säkerställa att a) ålders- och könsanpassad service för barns skydd finns tillgänglig i de utvalda områdena, och att b) samhällen och familjer i de utvalda områdena har kunskap och färdigheter för att skydda barn.
De två huvudsakliga output-målen adresserar så väl tillgång som efterfrågan av barns skydd. Att stärka det nationella ärendehanteringssystemet ligger i fokus i den övergripande komponenten och de föreslagna interventionerna är förenliga med och stärker den nationella åtgärdsplanen kring våld mot barn i Zimbabwe.
Bidraget på 49 miljoner SEK ska vara tematiskt stöd till UNICEF:s landprogram mellan 2016 och 2018. 400 000 SEK avsätts för utvärdering och uppföljning. DFID och Swiss Development Cooperation kommer samtidigt att bidra med stöd till det harmoniserade kontantöverföringsprogrammet (harmonised cash transfers, HCT), vilket utgör en stor del i att minska utsatthet.

UNICEF has applied for funding of SEK 49.4 million for support for its country program regarding the thematic areas of Child Protection and Social Inclusion between 2016 and 2018. The components and results of the proposed intervention have a strong equality and rights-based focus, with Social Inclusion 'As an overall theme as well as integrated with Children's Protection, HIV and Aids, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene and Education.
The intervention is in line with Swedish priorities, which aim to strengthen children's rights as part of social inclusion and poverty reduction. Sida's human rights perspective places children at the heart of the development agenda.
The social inclusion area will define strategies for strengthening resilience, especially in vulnerable areas that are particularly vulnerable to extreme climate such as drought. There is an urgent need to work with preventive interventions to protect children from suffering. The proposed interventions shall ensure that: (a) age and gender-based child protection services are available in the selected areas; and (b) communities and families in the selected areas have knowledge and skills to protect children.
The two main output targets address as well access as the demand for child protection. Strengthening the national case management system is the focus of the overall component, and the proposed interventions are consistent with and strengthening the National Action Plan on Violence Against Children in Zimbabwe.
The contribution of SEK 49 million will be thematic support for UNICEF's country program between 2016 and 2018. 400,000 SEK is allocated for evaluation and follow-up. DFID and Swiss Development Cooperation will simultaneously support the Harmonized Cash Transfer (HCT), which is a major component in reducing vulnerability.

description.narrative: The Child Protection Fund (CPF), implemented by UNICEF, in partnership with the Ministry of Public Service, Labour and Social Welfare (MoPSLSW) has strengthen the social welfare system, particularly statutory child protection work, and has consolidated a national case management (MIS) system, as well as expanded community prevention strategies and continuation of support supervision work for Probation Officers in the 18 districts where it has been implemented. Sweden has supported the CPF II since 2016, with the main goal to realize the basic rights of the most vulnerable children in Zimbabwe through provision of critical child protection interventions, within a child and HIV-sensitive social protection framework. It builds on the CPF Phase I (2011-2016), adopting a multi-dimensional poverty approach to child vulnerability which simultaneously addresses household poverty, gender disparities, disability, HIV and risk of violence, exploitation and gender-based abuse. Taking lessons from CPF I and CPF II, UNICEF has now submitted a request for a third phase, in order to increase focus on prevention of domestic violence through prevention, as well as enhancing the information management and governance structures and capacity. UNICEF has gradually stepped up upstream advocacy work for political commitment and support for child protection in partnership with Government. UNICEF supported the standardization of child protection business processes in line with the national case management standards in all districts. Despite the political and electoral processes that crowded out the social sector legislative processes, the Child Protection team continued to invest in legislative and policy review, ensured that the Harmonized Marriages Bill, the Children’s Bill and the Child Justice Bill remained on the legislative agenda. Focus in 2019 will now be in pursuing finalization and enactment of critical legislation affecting legal protection of children and the approval by Treasury to finance Non-Public Probation Officers. UNICEF has also made significant contributions to the language and advancement of the Children’s Bill, Child Justice Bill, the Harmonised Marriages Bill and the Cybercrime Bill. For the former three, adoption by Parliament is expected by the last quarter of 2019 which is a positive result. The priority focus should remain on the afore-mentioned new legislation plus revisions to the existing Forensics Act, Disabled Person’s Act, Marriages Act, and Criminal Procedure and Evidence Act.
